thread.title: Florida-bound Norwegian Escape heads to sea
thread.title_full: Florida-bound Norwegian Escape heads to sea

author: Richard Tribou
title: Florida-bound Norwegian Escape heads to sea
text:
Watch Norwegian Escape make its way from shipyard to sea 
What will be Norwegian Cruise Line's biggest ship is getting a little bit closer to Miami. 
Norwegian Escape made its way from the Meyer Werft shipyards in Papenburg, Germany on what's known as its conveyance down the Ems River on its way to begin sea trials in the North Sea. Caption Norwegian Escape conveyance Meyer Werft 
Norwegian Escape made its way along the Ems River toward the North Sea from Meyer Werft shipyards in Papenburg, Germany before it begins sea trials ahead of its October handover to Norwegian Cruise Line. 
Norwegian Escape made its way along the Ems River toward the North Sea from Meyer Werft shipyards in Papenburg, Germany before it begins sea trials ahead of its October handover to Norwegian Cruise Line. (Meyer Werft) Caption Norwegian Escape conveyance Meyer Werft 
Norwegian Escape made its way along the Ems River toward the North Sea from Meyer Werft shipyards in Papenburg, Germany before it begins sea trials ahead of its October handover to Norwegian Cruise Line. 
Norwegian Escape made its way along the Ems River toward the North Sea from Meyer Werft shipyards in Papenburg, Germany before it begins sea trials ahead of its October handover to Norwegian Cruise Line. (Meyer Werft) See more galleries 
"After seeing firsthand this week how spectacular Norwegian Escape already looks, I am thrilled that she is officially on her journey to welcome guests next month," said Norwegian Cruise Line President and COO Andy Stuart in a press release. "As the first Breakaway Plus class ship, she will offer the very best in freedom and flexibility for our guests and we cannot wait to officially welcome her to the fleet." 
The ship won't be handed over to the cruise line until Oct. 22 and won't begin sailing out of PortMiami until November, but the 4,200-passenger, 164,600-ton ship made the 24-hour-long trip along the north-flowing river from Friday into Saturday. It was assisted by tugboats and had to travel stern-first (as in backward) to make the journey.
